title: Steve Lopez of the Los Angeles Times

und.safe_value: For purposeful columns about rising homelessness in Los Angeles, which amplified calls for government action to deal with a long-visible public crisis.

title: Sally Jenkins of The Washington Post

und.safe_value: For columns that marshal a broad knowledge of history and culture to remind the sports world of its responsibility to uphold basic values of equity, fairness and tolerance.

title: Soraya Nadia McDonald of The Undefeated

und.safe_value: For essays on theater and film that bring a fresh, delightful intelligence to the intersections of race and art.

title: Justin Davidson of New York magazine

und.safe_value: For architecture reviews marked by a keen eye, deep knowledge and exquisite writing, as exemplified by his essay on Manhattan’s Hudson Yards development.

title: Chloé Cooper Jones, freelance reporter, The Verge

und.safe_value: For her gripping portrait of Ramsey Orta, who recorded the NYPD killing of Eric Garner, using restrained yet powerful language and courageous reporting to show the police retribution endured by a forgotten figure in a story that horrified the nation.

title: Ellen Barry of The New York Times

und.safe_value: For a beautifully written tale of an Indian “prince” whose story concealed deeper truths rooted in the violence and trauma of the Partition of India.

title: Nestor Ramos of The Boston Globe

und.safe_value: For a sweeping yet intimate story about how climate change is drastically reshaping Cape Cod, locally illustrating the urgent global crisis.

title: Melinda Henneberger of The Kansas City Star

und.safe_value: For her fierce and unflinching defense of the women of Missouri on issues of abortion access, sexual assault and domestic violence.

title: Jill Burcum of the Star Tribune, Minneapolis, Minn.

und.safe_value: For passionate, persuasive writing about a pristine wilderness area, accessible largely by canoe, to demonstrate to readers why a proposed mine would do incalculable environmental damage.

title: Kevin Kallaugher, freelancer

und.safe_value: For combining classically beautiful cartoon art and incisive wit to create a striking portfolio addressing the Trump administration, international affairs and local Baltimore politics.

title: Lalo Alcaraz, freelancer

und.safe_value: For irreverent and poignant cartoon commentary focused on local and national issues from a distinctly Latinx perspective.

title: Matt Bors of The Nib

und.safe_value: For cartoons that sliced through the hypocrisy of the Trump presidency, as well as the blind spots of moderate Democrats in a distinct, contemporary style.

title: Rosanna Xia, Swetha Kannan and Terry Castleman of the Los Angeles Times

und.safe_value: For a deeply researched examination of the difficult choices Californians must make as climate change erodes precious coastline.

title: Staff of Reveal from The Center for Investigative Reporting

und.safe_value: For its industrious reporting on worker injuries and the human toll of robotics technology at Amazon warehouses across the United States.

title: Jay Hancock and Elizabeth Lucas of Kaiser Health News

und.safe_value: For exposing predatory bill collection by the University of Virginia Health System that relentlessly squeezed low-income patients—many into bankruptcy—forcing the non-profit, state-run hospital to change its tactics.

title: Staff of The Wall Street Journal

und.safe_value: For an exhaustive investigation into Amazon, the world’s largest retailer, that revealed a largely unregulated and highly profitable third-party flea market and the potentially deadly results of it peddling of unsafe and banned products.

title: Staff of The Wall Street Journal

und.safe_value: For revelatory work showing how a California utility’s neglect of its equipment caused countless wildfires, including one that wiped out the town of Paradise and killed 85 people.

title: Staff of Reuters

und.safe_value: For a series of deeply-reported, original dispatches from the Hong Kong protests, a battleground between democracy and autocracy that detailed China's grip behind the scenes and offered valuable insights into the forces that will shape the next century.

title: Staff of The New York Times

und.safe_value: For gripping accounts that disclosed China’s top-secret efforts to repress millions of Muslims through a system of labor camps, brutality and surveillance.

title: Tom Fox of The Dallas Morning News

und.safe_value: For coverage of a would-be shooter outside Dallas’ Earle Cabell Federal Building, which houses federal courts, photographed at great personal risk.

title: Mary F. Calvert, freelance photographer

und.safe_value: For work published by The New York Times and Yahoo News that look intimately at male sexual assault survivors in the armed forces, and the lasting effects of trauma on them and their families.

title: Erin Clark of The Boston Globe

und.safe_value: For respectful and compassionate photography of a working Maine family as it falls into homelessness and finds new housing, albeit precarious.

title: Dieu Nalio Chery and Rebecca Blackwell of Associated Press

und.safe_value: For images from Haiti, conveying the horrors of lynching, murder and human rights abuses as the country wrestles with ongoing unrest.

title: Staff of The Boston Globe

und.safe_value: For its engaging approach to exposing socioeconomic inequities by surveying the city’s brightest public high school students a decade after graduation.

title: Staff of the Los Angeles Times

und.safe_value: For dynamic coverage that expertly blended multimedia components, frequent updates and rich narrative to report on a devastating California boat fire that killed 34 people.

title: Ben Lerner

und.safe_value: A brilliant and ambitious exploration of language, family and American identity as exemplified by the life of a Midwestern high school debate champion.
The Topeka School
Farrar, Straus and Giroux

title: Ann Patchett

und.safe_value: A masterful and beautifully rendered allegory of the destructive force of social ambition on several generations of a Pennsylvania family.
The Dutch House
Harper

title: Keeanga-Yamahtta Taylor

und.safe_value: A deeply researched and rigorously argued account of the public-private partnership that replaced redlining with even more predatory and destructive practices.
Race for Profit: How Banks and the Real Estate Industry Undermined Black Homeownership
University of North Carolina Press

title: the late Deirdre Bair

und.safe_value: A tale of authorial ambition, self-doubt and achievement that offers intriguing insight into the world of two of the 20th century’s literary giants and the art of biography itself.
Parisian Lives: Samuel Beckett, Simone de Beauvoir, And Me
Nan A. Talese/Doubleday

title: George Packer

und.safe_value: An inventive, compulsively readable life of a complicated man of considerable talents and personal failings that offers extraordinary insights into the inner workings of Washington's foreign policy establishment.
Our Man: Richard Holbrooke and the End of the American Century
Alfred A. Knopf

title: Dorianne Laux

und.safe_value: Poetic narratives of plainspoken authenticity with characters whose breadth spans the wide range of American life.
Only as the Day Is Long: New and Selected Poems
W.W. Norton

title: Mary Ruefle

und.safe_value: Poems of wildness and wit that swerve away from the predictable as they balance comedy and melancholy.
Dunce
Wave Books

title: Louise Aronson

und.safe_value: An empathetic and nuanced critique, informed by the author’s decades of experience as a geriatrician, of the ways in which our society and healthcare system neglect, stereotype and mistreat the elderly.
Elderhood: Redefining Aging, Transforming Medicine, Reimagining Life
Bloomsbury

title: Albert Woodfox with Leslie George

und.safe_value: An unflinching indictment of Louisiana's most notorious prison and the racist criminal justice system as told through an innocent man's redemptive journey faced with a life sentence in solitary confinement.
Solitary
Grove Atlantic

title: Will Arbery

und.safe_value: A scrupulously hewn drama centering on four alumni of a conservative Catholic college who confront themselves and each other, clashing over theology, politics and personal responsibility.
Heroes of the Fourth Turning

title: David Henry Hwang and Jeanine Tesori

und.safe_value: A multi-layered and mischievous musical that deconstructs a beloved, original American art form to examine the promise and the limits of representation in both the theatrical and political senses of the word.
Soft Power

title: Alex Weiser

und.safe_value: Recording released April 12, 2019 by Cantaloupe Music, a song cycle for voice, piano, percussion and string trio, based on poems in Yiddish and English, a meditative and deeply spiritual work whose unexpected musical language is arresting and directly emotional.
and all the days were purple

title: Michael Torke

und.safe_value: Premiered on January 5, 2019, in Troy, N.Y., a composition that merges traditions of bluegrass and classical music through the musical instrument common to both forms, a virtuosic work of astonishing beauty, expert pacing and generous optimism.
Sky: Concerto for Violin

title: The Washington Post

und.safe_value: For groundbreaking, data-driven journalism that used previously hidden government records and confidential company documents to provide unprecedented insight into America’s deadly opioid epidemic.

title: The New York Times

und.safe_value: For exemplary reporting that exposed the breadth and impact of a political war on science, including systematic dismantling of federal regulations and policy.

title: Andrew Beck Grace, Chip Brantley, Graham Smith, Nicole Beemsterboer and Robert Little of NPR

und.safe_value: For “White Lies,” a riveting seven-episode podcast that doggedly reinvestigated one of the most infamous murders of the Civil Rights era.

title: Nigel Poor, Earlonne Woods and Rahsaan Thomas

und.safe_value: For “Ear Hustle,” a consistently surprising and beautifully crafted series on life behind bars produced by inmates of San Quentin State Prison.

title: Staff of The Washington Post

und.safe_value: For incisive coverage of back-to-back mass shootings in El Paso, Texas and Dayton, Ohio that contextualized these events for a national audience.

title: Peter Smith, Stephanie Strasburg and Shelly Bradbury of the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

und.safe_value: For an unprecedented investigation of child sexual abuse and cover-ups in the insular Amish and Mennonite communities.

title: Greg Grandin

und.safe_value: A sweeping and beautifully written book that probes the American myth of boundless expansion and provides a compelling context for thinking about the current political moment (Moved by the Board to the General Nonfiction category, where it was also entered.)
The End of the Myth: From the Frontier to the Border Wall in the Mind of America
Metropolitan Books
